title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions to address disparities in polling place availability. Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents issued by Indian tribes to be treated as valid for voting purposes. The Attorney General may take legal action if disparities in in-person voting opportunities are found. The Attorney General can take legal action for disparities in in-person voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes compared to non-members. This includes increasing polling place availability. The district courts have jurisdiction over such actions, heard by a three-judge court with appeal to the Supreme Court. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over actions regarding disparities in voting opportunities, heard by a three-judge court with appeal to the Supreme Court. There is a presumption that such disparities may result in a denial of voting rights based on race or color. An aggrieved person can bring an action described in paragraph (1)(A) with the provisions of paragraph (2) applying to such action. SEC. 3. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Protections Relating to Indian Reservations under Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include requirements for approval before eliminating or moving polling places or voter registration sites on Indian reservations. Protections under the Voting Rights Act of 1965 require approval before moving or eliminating polling places or voter registration sites on Indian reservations, to prevent voter disenfranchisement. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 prohibits the removal or reduction of early voting locations on Indian reservations, ensuring voting opportunities are not diminished for Native American communities. The act also amends section 5(a) to include activities described in subsection (g) of section 4. Federal election oversight on Indian reservations is addressed in Section 4. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if a written complaint is received regarding potential voter rights violations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if a written complaint is received about potential voter rights violations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to terminate election observers appointed under specific conditions after the next general election for the office of President. Additionally, definitions are provided in the following section. SEC. 6 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to define terms related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations. SEC. 7 addresses bilingual election requirements and defines Indian reservation. SEC. 7 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 to update bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation. SEC. 8 requires the Attorney General to publicly release reports of Federal election observers. SEC. 9 addresses tribal voting consultation. The Attorney General must release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. Additionally, the Attorney General should consult annually with tribal organizations on voting issues for Indian tribe members.
